awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: A Dual-Band Radar for Measuring Internal Ice Deformation: a Multipass Ice-Penetrating Radar Experiment on Thwaites Glacier and the McMurdo Ice Shelf
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop a new ice-penetrating radar system that can simultaneously map glacier geometry and glacier flow along repeat profiles. Forecasting an ice-sheet’s contribution to sea level requires an estimate for the initial ice-sheet geometry and the parameters that govern ice flow and slip across bedrock. Existing ice-sheet models cannot independently determine this information from conventional observations of ice-surface velocities and glacier geometry. This introduces substantial uncertainty into simulations of past and future ice-sheet behavior. Thus, this new radar capability is conceived to provide the needed data to support higher-fidelity simulations of past and future ice-sheet behavior and more accurate projections of future sea level.

The new radar system will integrate two existing radars (the multi-channel coherent radio-echo depth sounder and the accumulation radar) developed by the Center for the Remote Sensing of Ice Sheets, as well as adding new capabilities.  An eight-element very high frequency (VHF; 140-215 MHz) array will have sufficient cross-track aperture to swath map internal layers and the ice-sheet base in three dimensions. A single ultra high frequency (UHF; 600-900 MHz) antenna will have the range and phase resolution to map internal layer displacement with 0.25-mm precision. The VHF array will create 3D mappings of layer geometry that enable measurements of vertical velocities by accounting for spatial offsets between repeat profiles and changing surface conditions. The vertical displacement measurement will then be made by determining the difference in radar phase response recorded by the UHF antenna for radar profiles collected at the same locations at different times. The UHF antenna will be dual-polarized and thus capable of isolating both components of complex internal reflections.  This should enable inferences of ice crystal orientation fabric and widespread mapping of ice viscosity. Initial field testing of the radar will occur on the McMurdo Ice Shelf and then progress to Thwaites Glacier, Antarctica. The dual-band radar system technology and processing algorithms will be developed with versatile extensible hardware and user-friendly software so that this system will serve as a prototype for a future community radar system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported construction and field testing of a dual-band polarimetric ice-penetrating radar capable of measuring englacial vertical deformation and ice crystal orientation fabric along a profile of the ice sheet while simultaneously swath mapping ice-sheet internal layers and bedrock topography in three dimensions over a cross-track width of approximately one kilometer. The new dual-band polarimetric radar system operates over both the 140-215 MHz (VHF) and 600-900 MHz (UHF) frequency ranges using a total of eight VHF elements with sufficient cross-track aperture to swath map internal layers and the bed topography beneath the ice, and a dual-polarization UHF antenna with sufficient range and phase resolution to map glacier internal displacement with sub-millimeter precision. Due to a new antenna design, employing four antennas in along-track for both transmit and receive, and an increase of transmit power from 10W to 1600 W, the UHF radar sensitivity is improved by 34 dB compared to the previous ground-based UHF system. This project successfully deployed this new radar system at numerous sites in Antarctica and Greenland, including: Eastwind Glacier and the McMurdo Ice Shelf, Nansen Ice Shelf, Thwaites Glacier, central West Antarctica, and northeast Greenland.  At these sites, the radar system mapped layers to greater than 2000 m depth and imaged the bed at depths close to 3000 m, which exceed expectations.

An explicit goal of this project was to design a radar system that is a prototype for a future community radar system with user-friendly hardware and software, so radar specialists do not need to be present to deploy and operate the radar. Two successful deployments to support other NSF-funded projects in Greenland demonstrate that the project met this goal. Numerous additional research groups are interested in adopting this radar for their own applications. The open-source polarimetric radar processing software developed by this project, incorporated into the larger Open Polar Radar toolbox, is now being used by radar scientists external to the project to understand ice crystal orientation fabric and rheology in glaciers on both Earth and Mars.

Scientifically, results using this radar have already led to several advancements. This radar revealed internal deformation of the McMurdo Ice Shelf due to tidal flexure (bending on sub-daily timescales), with possible ramifications for stability of this logistically important ice shelf, which serves as an operational hub for the US Antarctic Program. On Thwaites Glacier, this radar imaged shallow (less than 500 m depth) crystal fabric re-orientation associated with ice-stream shear margins, suggesting the need to consider both ice temperature and structure when determining shear-margin stability and migration. Finally, in northeast Greenland, radar data collected with this system suggest that large anomalous structures in the lower half of the ice sheet include sediment entrainment several hundred meters into the ice column. This project supported three PhD students studying electrical engineering and geophysics.
